elements.content: Eight polyoxometalate (POM)-based frameworks were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, using different octamolybdate isomers (Mo8) and copper-organic fragments or organic units in the presence of different bases. These compounds are named as [CuI(bix)][(CuIbix)(δ-Mo8O26)0.5] (1), H(CuIbix)[(CuIbix)2(β-Mo8O26)]·2H2O (2), H3[CuI(bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5](β-Mo8O26)0.5·2H2O (3), (H2bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5(β-Mo8O26)0.5·H2O (4), (H2bix)[(Hbix)2(γ-Mo8O26)]·2H2O (5), H2bix(γ-Mo8O26)0.5·H2O (6), [CuI(bpp)][CuI(bpp)(α-Mo8O26)0.5]·H2O (7), and [(H2bpp)2(β-Mo8O26)] (8) [bix = 1,4-bis(imidazole-1-ylmethyl)benzene, bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane]. Their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In compounds 1 and 2, four copper cations are linked by octamolybdate isomers to generate a 2D layer with (4,4) sheet, which is pillared by bix ligands to form a 3D (4,4)-connected framework with (64·82)(84·122) and (62·81)2(62·82·102) topologies, respectively. With the peneation of the copper-organic polymeric chains, a 3D polythreaded framework was formed. Compound 3 has a 3D supramolecular network based upon (β-Mo8O26)4− anions and copper-organic units, with guest (β-Mo8O26)4− anions included. In compound 4, a 3D supramolecular arrangement is constructed by the hydrogen-bond interactions between (β-Mo8O26)4− polyanions from different 2D structures and bix ligands. Compound 5 exhibits a unique bisupported structure built from Mo−N covalent bonds between (γ-Mo8O26)4- anions and bix ligands. This compound represents a rare example of organic-molecule-functionalized POM clusters that can be synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. In compound 6, a 3D supramolecular net is generated by hydrogen bonding interactions among water molecules, oxygen atoms of octamolybdate and nitrogen atoms of bix ligands. In compound 7, the bpp ligands link Cu cations and (α-Mo8O26)4− anions to generate a 1D ladder-like chain. [Cu(bpp)]2 2+ fragments further connect with (α-Mo8O26)4- anions from different chains to form a 2D (3,4)-connected layer with (4281)(6184101) topology. Compound 8 also has 3D supramolecular framework based on C−H···O hydrogen bonds between bpp and (β-Mo8O26)4− polyoxoanions. It is proposed that the different basicity, steric hindrance, and reducing strength of the bases used are the key factors in generating different Mo8 isomers in the reaction process, and thus the different frameworks as seen in 1−8. A ligand synergetic effect is also taken into account to explain the presence of the same Mo8 isomers in 7 and 8, which were synthesized with different bases. IR, TG, and electrochemistry study were performed to further characterize these compounds.

elements.content: One interesting topic in crystal design and material engineering is to build novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). Well-designed MOFs can bear interesting topologies, and their specific structures have potential applications in medicine assay, biological analysis, as well as gas storage, ion exchange and catalysis. In consideration of the varieties of topologies and properties, incorporating functional moieties into MOFs is often a popular way for the crystal design. As a unique class of metal-oxide clusters with controllable shape and size, highly negative charges, and oxo-enriched surfaces, polyoxometalates (POMs) represent one important candidate in the design and synthesis of new functional MOFs. A combination of “functions” from POMs and specific “structures” of MOFs is advantageous in designing new materials with novel chemical and physical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

One interesting topic in crystal design and material engineering is to build novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). Well-designed MOFs can bear interesting topologies, and their specific structures have potential applications in medicine assay, biological analysis, as well as gas storage, ion exchange and catalysis. In consideration of the varieties of topologies and properties, incorporating functional moieties into MOFs is often a popular way for the crystal design. As a unique class of metal-oxide clusters with controllable shape and size, highly negative charges, and oxo-enriched surfaces, polyoxometalates (POMs) represent one important candidate in the design and synthesis of new functional MOFs. A combination of "functions" from POMs and specific "structures" of MOFs is advantageous in designing new materials with novel chemical and physical properties.

elements.content: Four considerations need to be taken into account when designing POM-based MOFs. First of all is to find an ideal POM building block. POM clusters bearing different isomers are the best choices. The presence of different isomers makes possible the construction of diverse supramolecular isomers and polymorphs. Second of all is to choose suitable metal ions. The best choices should be easily ligated, and in various coordination modes. These properties are beneficial for them to link the POM building blocks and organic ligands into POM-based MOFs, and meanwhile generate framework topology diversity. Third of all is to choose a proper organic ligand. Generally, ligands with flexible structures are the first choice. These ligands can tolerate large structure twist and acquire the desirable coordination environment for metal ions. This provides advantages in designing crystal structures with polycatenation, polythreading, and polyknotting frameworks. The last consideration is to choose good structure-directing agents (SDAs). Properly chosen SDAs can effectively modify the reaction microenvironment, leading to crystals with desirable structures and properties. In the synthesis of POM-based MOFs, frequently used SDAs include metal cations, organic ligands, and bases.

elements.content: Octamolybdate (Mo8), as an important category of POM clusters, is a popularly used MOF building block. It has eight isomers, α, β, γ, δ, ε, ζ, η, and θ. These isomers are easily transformed with each other under mild environment modifications. Meanwhile, Mo8 can be easily made under hydrothermal conditions from (NH4)6Mo7O24 with controlled pH values. Different Mo8-based MOFs have been reported and the control factors for the formation of different frameworks have been studied. For example, Su and co-workers reported six Mo8-based hybrid materials, and quantitatively controlled the transformation of CuII ions into CuI in the POM-based MOFs. Briceño et al. regioselectively isolated rtct-tetrapyridylcyclobutanes (tpcb) compounds using Mo8 isomers under hydrothermal conditions. Hu and co-workers synthesized a noncovalently assembled framework based on Mo8 building blocks, (Hcpy)3[Ag(β-Mo8O26)] (cpy = 4-(5-chloropyridin-2-yl)pyridine). Lu and co-workers obtained a series of hybrid compounds based on Ag ions, 1,2,4-triazole, and POMs with structures varying from diverse supramolecular assemblies to 3-D rod-packing framework. Our research group reported two supramolecular isomers with a polythreaded topology based on Mo8 building blocks, [Cu(bbi)]2[Cu2(bbi)2(δ-Mo8O26)0.5][α-Mo8O26]0.5 and [Cu(bbi)][Cu(bbi)(θ-Mo8O26)0.5] [bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole)]. With the ligand effect well-studied, a detailed study of the base effect should provide more insight into the design of Mo8-based MOFs.

elements.content: In this work, four reaction systems were designed to study the effect of different bases (NaOH, en and TEA) on the structure of Mo8-based frameworks, as shown in Scheme . Eight compounds [CuI(bix)][(CuIbix)(δ-Mo8O26)0.5] (1), H(CuIbix)[(CuIbix)2(β-Mo8O26)]·2H2O (2), H3[CuI(bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5](β-Mo8O26)0.5·2H2O (3), (H2bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5(β-Mo8O26)0.5·H2O (4), (H2bix)[(Hbix)2(γ-Mo8O26)]·2H2O (5), H2bix(γ-Mo8O26)0.5·H2O (6), [CuI(bpp)][CuI(bpp)(α-Mo8O26)0.5]·H2O (7), and [(H2bpp)2(β-Mo8O26)] (8) were successfully isolated and crystallographically characterized. IR, TG, and electrochemical study were also conducted to further authenticate the identity of these compounds.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. The ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) was prepared based on a literature procedure. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer, and Mo and Cu were determined with a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer. TG analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. A CHI 660 Electrochemical Workstation connected to a Digital-586 personal computer was used to conduct the electrochemical measurements and data collection. A conventional three-electrode system was used. The working electrodes are 1−8 bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes. A SCE was used as the reference electrode and Pt gauze as the counter electrode. The working electrode was prepared following our earlier method.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. The ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) was prepared based on a literature procedure. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer, and Mo and Cu were determined with a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer. TG analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. A CHI 660 Electrochemical Workstation connected to a Digital-586 personal computer was used to conduct the electrochemical measurements and data collection. A conventional three-electrode system was used. The working electrodes are 1-8 bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes. A SCE was used as the reference electrode and Pt gauze as the counter electrode. The working electrode was prepared following our earlier method.

elements.content: [CuI(bix)][(CuIbix)(δ-Mo8O26)0.5] (1). A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), bix (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(OAc)2·H2O (0.099 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (6 mL) was adjusted to pH 3 with HCl (1 M) and NaOH (1 M). The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and sealed. After being heated at 150 °C for 72 h, it was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h−1. Yellow crystals of 1 were collected in 46.4% yield based on Mo. Calcd for C28H28Cu2Mo4N8O13 (1195.42): C, 28.13; H, 2.36; N, 9.37; Mo, 32.10; Cu, 10.63%. Found: C, 28.25; H, 2.43; N, 9.29; Mo, 32.24; Cu, 10.46%.

Syntheses

[CuI(bix)][(CuIbix)(δ-Mo8O26)0.5] (1). A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24⋅4H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), bix (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O (0.099 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (6 mL) was adjusted to pH 3 with HCl (1 M) and NaOH (1 M). The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and sealed. After being heated at 150 °C for 72 h, it was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C⋅h-1. Yellow crystals of 1 were collected in 46.4% yield based on Mo. Calcd for C28H28Cu2Mo4N8O13 (1195.42): C, 28.13; H, 2.36; N, 9.37; Mo, 32.10; Cu, 10.63%. Found: C, 28.25; H, 2.43; N, 9.29; Mo, 32.24; Cu, 10.46%.

elements.content: Diffractive quality single crystals were mounted on a glass fiber and the crystallographic data of 1−8 were collected at 150(2) K on a Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and IP technique. The structures of 1−8 were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms on the C atoms were included in calculated positions. The H atoms on water molecules cannot be found from the weak residual electron peaks but directly included in the final molecular formula. The detailed crystal data and structure refinement for 1−8 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths of them are given in Table S2a−2h (see the ). Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallography Data Centre (CCDC) as deposition numbers CCDC 723237−723244 for 1−8. In these compounds, Cu and Mo exhibit +I and +VI oxidation states, which were confirmed by charge neutrality, coordination environments, and valence sum calculations.

Structure Description of <bold>1</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there are one (δ-Mo8O26)4− anion, two CuI (Cu1 and Cu2) cations, and two bix (bix1 and bix2) ligands (see Figure S9a) in the asymmetric unit of 1 (Figure a). The peculiar (δ-Mo8O26)4− anion consists of four distorted {MoO6} octahedra and four distorted {MoO4} tetrahedra, with three kinds of O atoms, two μ3-O, ten μ2-O, and fourteen terminal oxygen atoms (Ot). Here, each Cu1 cation has a four-coordinated tetrahedral geometry which is defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different bix1 ligands with the distances of Cu(1)−N(6) = 1.887(1) and Cu(1)−N(8)#2 = 1.892(2) Å, and two terminal oxygen atoms from two (δ-Mo8O26)4− anions with Cu(1)−O(12)#4 = 2.610(5) and Cu(1)−O(6)#1 = 2.627(4) Å. Cu2 shows closely linear geometry, which is completed by two nitrogen atoms from two bix2 ligands (Cu(2)−N(1) = 1.878(8) and Cu(2)−N(4)#3 = 1.873(1) Å). In 1, the (δ-Mo8O26)4− anion coordinates to four Cu1 cations via four terminal oxygen atoms to generate a 2D (4,4) sheet, with grid sizes of 13.6 × 13.6 Å2 (Figure b and Figure S1 in the ). The Cu1 cations from different 2D sheets are linked together by bix1 ligands with GG conformations (G = gauche) to form a unique 3D metal organic framework. Furthermore, the 3D framework is penetrated by [CuI(bix)]+ chains based on Cu2 cations and bix2 ligands in TT conformations (T = trans). From the topological view to analyze the main 3D framework, each (δ-Mo8O26)4− anion and Cu1 cations can be considered as four-connected nodes, and the bix ligands as linkages. As a result, compound 1 shows a 3D (4,4)-connected framework with the (64·82)(84·122) topology (Figure c). The 3D polythreaded framework including the [CuI(bix)]+ chains is shown in Figure d and Figure S1b, c in the .

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there are one kind of (β-Mo8O26)4− anion, two kinds of CuI (Cu1 and Cu2) cations, and two kinds of bix (bix1 and bix2) ligands (see Figure S9b in the ) in the asymmetric unit of 2 (Figure a). The (β-Mo8O26)4- anion consists of eight distorted {MoO6} octahedral with four kinds of O atoms, six μ2-O, four μ3-O, two μ5-O, and twelve Ot. Each Cu1 exhibits nearly linear coordination geometry formed by two nitrogen atoms from two bix2 (Cu(1)−N(1) = 1.859(2) Å). Cu2 has a four-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry completed by two nitrogen atoms from two bix1 with distances of Cu(2)−N(5) = 1.861(1) and Cu(2)−N(3) = 1.904(1) Å, and two terminal oxygen atoms from two (β-Mo8O26)4− anions with Cu(2)−O(7)#2 = 2.604(1) and Cu(2)−O(9) = 2.641(6) Å. The (β-Mo8O26)4− anion coordinates to four Cu2 cations with four terminal oxygen atoms to generate a 2D (4,4) sheet (Figure b) and Cu2 cations from different 2D sheets are connected with bix1 (GG) to form an intricate 3D MOF. As a result, the unusual polythreaded network is formed by [Cu(1)Ibix2]+ chains penetrating the 3D inorganic−organic hybrid frameworks. From the topological view to analyze the main 3D framework, Cu2 cations can be considered as three-connected nodes and each (β-Mo8O26)4- anion as a four-connected node, and bix ligands as linkages. Consequently, compound 2 exhibits a 3D (3,4)-connected framework with the (62·81)2(62·82·102) topology, which is shown in Figure c. The 3D polythreaded framework including free [CuI(bix)]+ fragments is shown in Figure d.

elements.content: Hitherto, most polythreaded nets are known for the octamolybdate systems with 3D α-Po topology framework such as [H2bbi][CuII(bbi)2(β-Mo8O26)] and [CuII(bbi)2(H2O)(β-Mo8O26)0.5]. Compounds 1 and 2 represent two novel 3D polythreaded frameworks with (64·82)(84·122) and (62·81)2(62·82·102) topology, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there are two types of (β-Mo8O26)4- anions, one type of CuI (Cu1) cation, and two types of bix (bix1 and bix2) ligands (see Figure S9c in the ) in the asymmetric unit of 3 (Figure a). Each Cu1 exhibits a four-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry constructed from two nitrogen atoms from two different bix ligands with the distances of Cu(1)−N(4) = 1.879(1) and Cu(1)−N(5) = 1.877(1) Å, and two terminal oxygen atoms from two (β-Mo8O26)4− anions with Cu(1)−O(3) = 2.605(5) and Cu(1)−O(11)#1 = 2.801(3) Å. The (β-Mo8O26)4− anion also coordinates to four Cu1 cations with four terminal oxygen atoms to construct a 1D chain (Figure b). This 1D chain extends to a 2D supramolecular layer by π−π stacking interactions between adjacent imidazole rings of different bix ligands with centroid−centroid distances of 3.651(1) Å (see Figure S2 in the ). Adjacent layers further interact to form 3D frameworks via hydrogen bonds between the terminal oxygen atoms of Mo8 anions and carbon atoms of bix ligands. Figure c shows the 3D supramolecular arrangement when partial β-Mo8 anions were included (Figure c).

elements.content: The unique (γ-Mo8O26)4− anion consists of six distorted {MoO6} octahedra and two distorted {MoO5N} octahedra with four kinds of O atoms, two μ4-O, four μ3-O, six μ2-O, and fourteen Ot. As shown in Figure a, the special Mo2 atom exhibits a six-coordinated distorted octahedral geometry constructed by two μ3-O atoms (O5 and O10), two terminal oxygen atoms (O1 and O8) and one μ2-O atom (O3) from the (γ-Mo8O26)4− anion, and one N atom from a bix1 ligand with the distances of Mo2−O5 = 2.079(4), Mo2−O10 = 2.286(7), Mo2−O1 = 1.704(4), Mo2−O8 = 1.713(3), Mo2−O3 = 1.878(1), and Mo2−N2 = 2.228(3) Å, respectively. The other Mo atoms of the (γ-Mo8O26)4− anion are also in distorted octahedral environments with Mo−O distances ranging from 1.698(5) to 2.432(5) Å within the reported values. Interestingly, bix1 ligands with GG conformations combined with Mo2 atoms via the Mo−N covalent bonds to build a bisupported structure [(Hbix)2(γ-Mo8O26)]2−. Common inorganic−organic hybrid compounds based on direct covalent bonds between POMs and organic amine are usually bulit from unhydrous organic solvents, inviting seriouw environmental problem. Compound 5 represents a rare case that comes from environmentally friendly aqueous solutions. The 1D chain (see Figure S3 in the ) was built from the π−π stacking interactions (3.400(8) Å) and hydrogen-bonding interactions between adjacent bisupported units and free water molecules. Interestingly, the presence of water molecule plays an important role in constructing the chain structure. The detail is shown in Figure S4 of the . Furthermore, free bix2 ligands in GG conformations are linked with the 1D chain by N−H···O hydrogen bonds with the distance of 2.701(3) Å to build a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The unique (γ-Mo8O26)4- anion consists of six distorted {MoO6} octahedra and two distorted {MoO5N} octahedra with four kinds of O atoms, two μ4-O, four μ3-O, six μ2-O, and fourteen Ot. As shown in Figure a, the special Mo2 atom exhibits a six-coordinated distorted octahedral geometry constructed by two μ3-O atoms (O5 and O10), two terminal oxygen atoms (O1 and O8) and one μ2-O atom (O3) from the (γ-Mo8O26)4- anion, and one N atom from a bix1 ligand with the distances of Mo2-O5 = 2.079(4), Mo2-O10 = 2.286(7), Mo2-O1 = 1.704(4), Mo2-O8 = 1.713(3), Mo2-O3 = 1.878(1), and Mo2-N2 = 2.228(3) Å, respectively. The other Mo atoms of the (γ-Mo8O26)4- anion are also in distorted octahedral environments with Mo-O distances ranging from 1.698(5) to 2.432(5) Å within the reported values. Interestingly, bix1 ligands with GG conformations combined with Mo2 atoms via the Mo-N covalent bonds to build a bisupported structure [(Hbix)2(γ-Mo8O26)]2-. Common inorganic-organic hybrid compounds based on direct covalent bonds between POMs and organic amine are usually bulit from unhydrous organic solvents, inviting seriouw environmental problem. Compound 5 represents a rare case that comes from environmentally friendly aqueous solutions. The 1D chain (see Figure S3 in the ) was built from the π-π stacking interactions (3.400(8) Å) and hydrogen-bonding interactions between adjacent bisupported units and free water molecules. Interestingly, the presence of water molecule plays an important role in constructing the chain structure. The detail is shown in Figure S4 of the . Furthermore, free bix2 ligands in GG conformations are linked with the 1D chain by N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds with the distance of 2.701(3) Å to build a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure c).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there is one kind of (γ-Mo8O26)4− anion and two kinds of bix (bix1 and bix2) ligands (see Figure S9f in the ) in the asymmetric unit of compound 6 (Figure a). In this compound, (γ-Mo8O26)4− anions are linked together by sharing terminal oxygen atoms (O4) to construct 1D POM chains (see Figure S5 in the ). The chain-like structures are then connected by bix to build a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure b) by N−H···O hydrogen bonds with N1−O9 = 2.651(5) Å. Furthermore, the 3D supramolecular framework (Figure d) was generated by hydrogen bonding interactions (Figure c) among water molecule, oxygen atoms of octamolybdate and nitrogen atoms of bix ligands with distances of N3−Ow1 = 2.764(2), Ow1−O11 = 2.875(4), and Ow1−O6 = 2.875(5) Å.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that there are one (α-Mo8O26)4− anion, two CuI (Cu1 and Cu2) cations and two bpp (bpp1 and bpp2) ligands (see Figure S9g in the ) in the asymmetric unit of compound 7 (Figure a). The (α-Mo8O26)4− anion consists of six distorted {MoO6} octahedra and two distorted {MoO4} tetrahedra with three kinds of O atoms, six μ3-O, six μ2-O, and fourteen Ot. The Cu1 cation is ligated by two nitrogen atoms (Cu1−N1 = 1.909(3) and Cu1−N2 = 1.887(3) Å) from two bpp1 ligands and two terminal oxygen atoms from different (α-Mo8O26)4− anions (Cu1−O3 = 2.526(7) and Cu1−O3#2 =v 2.674(4) Å) and shows a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Cu2 cation is ligated by two nitrogen atoms (Cu2−N3 = 1.899(2) and Cu2−N4 = 1.914(2) Å) from two bpp2 ligands and one terminal oxygen atom from the (α-Mo8O26)4− anion (Cu2−O10 = 2.326(3) Å) and shows a T-shaped coordination geometry. Bpp1 and bpp2 exhibit GG and TG conformations, respectively. The bpp2 ligands with bismonodentate coordination modes link Cu2 cations and (α-Mo8O26)4− anions to generate a 1D ladderlike chain (Figure b). Each [Cu1(bpp1)]2 2+ cation fragment coordinates to two terminal oxygen atoms of adjacent (α-Mo8O26)4− anions from different chains to form a 2D layer. From the topological view, if bpp is considered as linkages (Figure c), Cu2 cation as three-connected node and the (α-Mo8O26)4− anion as four-connected node, the structure of 7 can be symbolized as a (3,4)-connected layer with (4281)(6184101) topology (Figure d).

The bpp acts as a three-dentate ligand to link POMs to a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure b) with N2−O12 = 2.760(7), N1−O9 = 2.721(1), and N1−O7 = 2.878(3) Å. elements.content: Different basicity, steric hindrance, and reducing strength of the bases used are the key factors in generating different Mo8 isomers in the reaction process, and thus the different frameworks as seen in 1−8. With the initial pH value being the same, slight pH difference in the reaction process can be generated by the different releasing rate of OH− of different bases. This releasing rate controls the quantities of different Mo8 isomers in the reactions system. Organic bases (en and TEA) that release OH− ions slowly tend to generate the same Mo8 isomers (β-Mo8 in 2-3). Strong base NaOH which quickly releases OH− ions makes another Mo8 isomer (δ-Mo8 in 1) dominant in the solution. Meanwhile, the three bases (NaOH, en, TEA) have different steric hindrance. The relatively less bulky bases, NaOH and en, tend to direct the formation of a polythreaded strucuture, as seen in compounds 1 and 2. Bulky TEA molecules tend to direct the formation of supramolecular cavities including POM anions. Furthermore, reducing organic bases would transform Cu(II) into Cu(I), which can tolerate various coordination geometries such as linear, “T-shaped”, or distorted tetrahedral. The diversity of the coordination modes of Cu(I) can lead to the diversity of crystallographic frameworks. In compounds 7 and 8, the Mo8 isomers are the same in spite of using different bases. This is explained by the synergic effect of the ligands used. In compounds 7 and 8, flexible pyridyl ligands were used. A relative rigid imidazole ligand was used in compounds 1−6.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the Bases on the Structure of Mo8 Isomers and Compounds 1-8 

Different basicity, steric hindrance, and reducing strength of the bases used are the key factors in generating different Mo8 isomers in the reaction process, and thus the different frameworks as seen in 1-8. With the initial pH value being the same, slight pH difference in the reaction process can be generated by the different releasing rate of OH- of different bases. This releasing rate controls the quantities of different Mo8 isomers in the reactions system. Organic bases (en and TEA) that release OH- ions slowly tend to generate the same Mo8 isomers (β-Mo8 in 2-3). Strong base NaOH which quickly releases OH- ions makes another Mo8 isomer (δ-Mo8 in 1) dominant in the solution. Meanwhile, the three bases (NaOH, en, TEA) have different steric hindrance. The relatively less bulky bases, NaOH and en, tend to direct the formation of a polythreaded strucuture, as seen in compounds 1 and 2. Bulky TEA molecules tend to direct the formation of supramolecular cavities including POM anions. Furthermore, reducing organic bases would transform Cu(II) into Cu(I), which can tolerate various coordination geometries such as linear, "T-shaped", or distorted tetrahedral. The diversity of the coordination modes of Cu(I) can lead to the diversity of crystallographic frameworks. In compounds 7 and 8, the Mo8 isomers are the same in spite of using different bases. This is explained by the synergic effect of the ligands used. In compounds 7 and 8, flexible pyridyl ligands were used. A relative rigid imidazole ligand was used in compounds 1-6.

elements.content: The IR spectra of compounds 1−8 are shown in Figure S6 of the . In the infrared spectrum of compound 1, the characteristic peaks at 914, 848, 726, 655 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). Bands in the 1631−1095 cm−1 regions in the infrared spectrum of compound 1 are attributed to characteristic peaks of bix groups. In compound 2, the characteristic peaks at 921, 665 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). A series of medium intensity bands in the 1639−1100 cm−1 range is associated with bix, and a broad and strong band at about 3444 cm−1 is associated with the lattice water. For compound 3, the characteristic peaks at 919, 667 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). Bands in the 1654−1099 cm−1 region are attributed to characteristic peaks of bix groups and a strong band at about 3442 cm−1 is associated with the lattice water. In compound 4, the characteristic peaks at 909, 661 cm−1 are attributed to ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). A series of medium intensity bands in the 1539−1087 cm−1 range is associated with bix, and a broad and strong band at about 3453 cm−1 is associated with the lattice water. For compound 5, the characteristic peaks at 902 and 654 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). Bands in the 1550−1093 cm−1 regions are attributed to characteristic peaks of bix groups and a strong band at about 3457 cm−1 is associated with the lattice water. In compound 6, the characteristic peaks at 924, 848, 675 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). A series of medium intensity bands in the 1567−1091 cm−1 range is associated with bix, and a broad and strong band at about 3450 cm−1 is associated with lattice water. For compound 7, the characteristic peaks at 910, 806, 659 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). Bands in the 1612−1208 cm−1 region are attributed to characteristic peaks of bpp groups and a strong band at about 3424 cm−1 is associated with the lattice water. In compound 8, the characteristic peaks at 936, 895, 670 cm−1 are attributed to the ν(Mo=Ot) or ν(Mo−O−Mo). A series of medium intensity bands in the 1695−1180 cm−1 range is associated with bpp.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−8 were determined on single-crystalline samples in the nitrogen atmosphere by thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) (see Figure S7 in the ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that chemical decomposition starts at 270 °C and ends at 480 °C with the weight loss of 40.25%, equivalent to the loss of two bix molecules (calcd, 39.87%). The TGA curve of 2 shows two weight loss processes. The one (1.84%) from 60 to 80 °C is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd, 1.69%). The other weight loss (33.82%) from 380 to 540 °C corresponds to the removal of three bix ligands (calcd, 33.67%). For 3, the weight loss of 2.18% from 70 to 90 °C is equivalent to the loss of two coordinated water molecules (calcd, 2.04%). The second weight loss of 27.46% from 264 to 557 °C corresponds to the loss of two bix ligands (calcd, 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (1.21%) from 70 to 85 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 1.07%); the other (28.76%) from 320 to 530 °C corresponds to the removal of two bix ligands (calcd, 28.57%). Compound 5 has two weight loss processes. The one (1.95%) from 70 to 80 °C is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd, 1.86%). Another weight loss (37.24%) from 300 to 510 °C corresponds to the removal of three bix ligands (calcd, 37.09%). Compound 6 has two weight loss processes. The one (2.26%) from 75 to 85 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 2.12%); the other one (28.43%) from 270 to 510 °C corresponds to the removal of a bix ligand (calcd, 28.27%). The TGA curve of 7 also shows two weight loss processes. The one (1.67%) from 45 to 55 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 1.59%). The other weight loss (34.86%) from 250 to 510 °C, corresponds to the removal of two bpp ligands (calcd, 34.99%). For compound 8, the one weight loss (25.43%) from 320 to 520 °C corresponds to the removal of two bpp ligands. (calcd, 25.29%).

elements.content: The electrochemical behaviors of compounds 1−8 were studied in a 0.1 M H2SO4 solution (see Figure S8 in the ). The cyclic voltammetric behaviors for 1−3 and 7 exhibit a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = −0.09, −0.06, −0.05, and −0.05 V {E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2} (E 1/2 is mean peak potentials, Epa is anodic peak potentials, E pc is cathodic peak potentials) versus SCE and an oxidation wave which is apparently irreversible with its peak at Epc = 0.20, 0.14, 0.15, and 0.14 V versus SCE, respectively (scan rate: 100 mV/s). The redox peak I−I′ might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV. Another cathodic irreversible oxidation peak should correspond to the redox process of CuI/CuII. The electrochemical behaviors for 4−6 and 8 show a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = 0.06, 0.03, −0.07, and −0.01 V versus SCE, respectively. The redox peak I−I′ might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV.

Electrochemistry Study

The electrochemical behaviors of compounds 1-8 were studied in a 0.1 M H2SO4 solution (see Figure S8 in the ). The cyclic voltammetric behaviors for 1-3 and 7 exhibit a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = -0.09, -0.06, -0.05, and -0.05 V {E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2} (E 1/2 is mean peak potentials, Epa is anodic peak potentials, E pc is cathodic peak potentials) versus SCE and an oxidation wave which is apparently irreversible with its peak at Epc = 0.20, 0.14, 0.15, and 0.14 V versus SCE, respectively (scan rate: 100 mV/s). The redox peak I-I' might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV. Another cathodic irreversible oxidation peak should correspond to the redox process of CuI/CuII. The electrochemical behaviors for 4-6 and 8 show a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = 0.06, 0.03, -0.07, and -0.01 V versus SCE, respectively. The redox peak I-I' might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have designed and synthesized eight POM-based hybrid materials based on different Mo8 isomers and copper-organic fragments or organic units directed by different kinds of bases under hydrothermal conditions. During the preparation of the eight compounds, we found that various bases (NaOH, en, and TEA) play different structure directing roles in the self-assembly process of Mo8-based frameworks. Moreover, the structure directing roles of bases are affected by synergy effect of organic ligands during the reaction. Additionally, the IR, TG, and electrochemical properties have been investigated in detail for all compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have designed and synthesized eight POM-based hybrid materials based on different Mo8 isomers and copper-organic fragments or organic units directed by different kinds of bases under hydrothermal conditions. During the preparation of the eight compounds, we found that various bases (NaOH, en, and TEA) play different structure directing roles in the self-assembly process of Mo8-based frameworks. Moreover, the structure directing roles of bases are affected by synergy effect of organic ligands during the reaction. Additionally, the IR, TG, and electrochemical properties have been investigated in detail for all compounds.

cln_elements.content:
[CuI(bix)][(CuIbix)(δ-Mo8O26)0.5] (1). A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), bix (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(OAc)2·H2O (0.099 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (6 mL) was adjusted to pH 3 with HCl (1 M) and NaOH (1 M). The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, and transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and sealed. After being heated at 150 °C for 72 h, it was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h−1. Yellow crystals of 1 were collected in 46.4% yield based on Mo. Calcd for C28H28Cu2Mo4N8O13 (1195.42): C, 28.13; H, 2.36; N, 9.37; Mo, 32.10; Cu, 10.63%. Found: C, 28.25; H, 2.43; N, 9.29; Mo, 32.24; Cu, 10.46%.

H(CuIbix)[(CuIbix)2(β-Mo8O26)]·2H2O (2). Using ethylenediamine (en) (1M) as the base, an otherwise same procedure as for 1 was used. Yellow crystals of 2 were collected in 50.6% yield based on Mo. Calcd for C42H47Cu3Mo8N12O28 (2126.06): C, 23.73; H, 2.23; N, 7.91; Mo, 36.10; Cu, 8.97%. Found: C, 23.82; H, 2.18; N, 7.86; Mo, 36.21; Cu, 9.12%.

H3[CuI(bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5](β-Mo8O26)0.5·2H2O (3). Using triethylamine (TEA) as the base, an otherwise same procedure as for 1 was used. Yellow crystals of 3 were collected in 60.2% yield based on Mo. Calcd for C28H35CuMo8N8O28 (1762.70): C, 19.08; H, 2.00; N, 6.36; Mo, 43.54; Cu, 3.61%. Found: C, 19.17; H, 2.08; N, 6.47; Mo, 43.66; Cu, 3.46%.

(H2bix)2(β-Mo8O26)0.5(β-Mo8O26)0.5·H2O (4). A mixture of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), bix (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (6 mL) was adjusted to pH = 4 with NaOH (1 M), and the resulting mixture was stirred for 0.5 h. The reaction mixture was then transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and sealed. After being heated at 150 °C for 72 h, it was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h−1. Yellow crystals of 4 were collected in 51.7% yield based on Mo. cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−8 were determined on single-crystalline samples in the nitrogen atmosphere by thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) (see Figure S7 in the ). For compound 1, TGA curve shows that chemical decomposition starts at 270 °C and ends at 480 °C with the weight loss of 40.25%, equivalent to the loss of two bix molecules (calcd, 39.87%). The TGA curve of 2 shows two weight loss processes. The one (1.84%) from 60 to 80 °C is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd, 1.69%). The other weight loss (33.82%) from 380 to 540 °C corresponds to the removal of three bix ligands (calcd, 33.67%). For 3, the weight loss of 2.18% from 70 to 90 °C is equivalent to the loss of two coordinated water molecules (calcd, 2.04%). The second weight loss of 27.46% from 264 to 557 °C corresponds to the loss of two bix ligands (calcd, 27.21%). The TGA curve of 4 has two weight loss processes. The one (1.21%) from 70 to 85 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 1.07%); the other (28.76%) from 320 to 530 °C corresponds to the removal of two bix ligands (calcd, 28.57%). Compound 5 has two weight loss processes. The one (1.95%) from 70 to 80 °C is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules (calcd, 1.86%). Another weight loss (37.24%) from 300 to 510 °C corresponds to the removal of three bix ligands (calcd, 37.09%). Compound 6 has two weight loss processes. The one (2.26%) from 75 to 85 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 2.12%); the other one (28.43%) from 270 to 510 °C corresponds to the removal of a bix ligand (calcd, 28.27%). The TGA curve of 7 also shows two weight loss processes. The one (1.67%) from 45 to 55 °C is attributed to the loss of free water (calcd, 1.59%). The other weight loss (34.86%) from 250 to 510 °C, corresponds to the removal of two bpp ligands (calcd, 34.99%). For compound 8, the one weight loss (25.43%) from 320 to 520 °C corresponds to the removal of two bpp ligands. (calcd, 25.29%).

Electrochemistry Study

The electrochemical behaviors of compounds 1−8 were studied in a 0.1 M H2SO4 solution (see Figure S8 in the ). The cyclic voltammetric behaviors for 1−3 and 7 exhibit a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = −0.09, −0.06, −0.05, and −0.05 V {E 1/2 = (E pa + E pc)/2} (E 1/2 is mean peak potentials, Epa is anodic peak potentials, E pc is cathodic peak potentials) versus SCE and an oxidation wave which is apparently irreversible with its peak at Epc = 0.20, 0.14, 0.15, and 0.14 V versus SCE, respectively (scan rate: 100 mV/s). The redox peak I−I′ might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV. Another cathodic irreversible oxidation peak should correspond to the redox process of CuI/CuII. The electrochemical behaviors for 4−6 and 8 show a chemically reversible redox pair at E 1/2 = 0.06, 0.03, −0.07, and −0.01 V versus SCE, respectively. The redox peak I−I′ might be ascribed to MoVI/MoV.
